text: [Music]
this is the video of the final moments
in the life of Charles Jason toll the
documents a cell extraction a
controversial procedure routinely used
in prisons and jails they give him
medication in there but there's no
therapy there's no learning how to cope
with your problems that was his first
picture from prison Jane Luna worried
about her son who is in and out of
prison for nonviolent crimes since he
was a teenager he had a history of drug
abuse and mental illness and he
attempted suicide several times inside
the Riverbend maximum-security
institution his condition worsened he
spent the last year of his life in
solitary confinement after being accused
of assaulting a corrections officer
[Music]
a blob doll on the night of August 17
2010 the night he died mr. tall had
allegedly splashed the liquid at a
corrections officer that drove Captain
James Horton to assemble a group of
officers known as a cell extraction team
to forcibly pull mr. toll out of his
cell in order to search him and the cell
he didn't have a chance he was cuffed
and shackled and you know and they kept
saying he was combative and how can you
be combative when you're laying on your
stomach your hands handcuffed behind
your back
and you're shackled how combative can
you be there are no national standards
for cell extractions which are
disproportionately used against mentally
ill inmates like mr. toll and the
process is widely recognized as
dangerous to both guards and prisoners
most prisons monitors cell extractions
by videotaping them in this case there
were two officers filming the scene the
video has been watched over and over
again by mr. tolls family and his
friends the way that they did it on
video with their voices knowing that it
could be seen and be heard it absolutely
tore me up to think that they are that
above the law mr. Chow's mother brought
a civil rights lawsuit against two of
the officers in the prison warden her
lawyers Jeff Roberts and David Weisman
argued that excessive force was used
against mr. tall and that it constituted
cruel and unusual punishment you hear
mr. tall complaining I can't breathe I
can't breathe somewhere between 11 to 14
times during a cell extraction at one
point in the video captain Horton says
words to the effect of you're not going
to be able to breathe mr. tall at
another point in time he says we're here
to help you buddy well I'm not sure how
they were helping I'm by crushing the
life out of him
in court hearings the officers defended
their actions and decisions
he was very belligerent I asked him to
back up to the pipe flap to be cuffed he
refused I told him if he didn't I was
gonna have to get a cell extraction team
he said bring it on
that's cell extraction based on what you

it was according to procedure procedure
as the way it should be done the
internal investigators said that it was
a perfect cell extraction and that he
was going to use it as a training tape
and they killed my child how was that a
perfect cell extraction in the end the
jury sided with the officers all the

the exception of one were you present at

altered his voice in this video they'd
do anything to preserve evidence they
cleaned out his entire cell bag
everything up they put it all in trash
bags and Lucas after he was dragged from

series of metal gates to the very last
cage in a prison yard where the lights

a place it was well with then it would
have been a whole lot different
situation it was pitch black out there
pitch black it's in the mid-80s
everybody's hot even the cert teams were

nobody said anything
somebody ID the Mason said something
often times people in the throes of
positional asphyxiation they will be

not know somebody is dead
when you're rolling them over and you're

he had bruising over his windpipe
indicating force was used on his neck
mr. tall was 33 years old what I saw on

they want to do it not the way they're

many experts are questioning how cell

at home I promised him when I went up to

I'm letting people know what happened to

maybe things will change and nobody's
